statement.tex: %text Let $A=\{1,2,3\}$, $B=\{4,5,6,7\}$ and let $f=\{(1,4), (2,5), (3,6)\}$ be a function from $A$ to $B$. State whether $f$ is one-one or not. %

step.context: %text Given $A=\{1,2,3\}$ and $B=\{4,5,6,7\}$ consider these functions from $A$ to $B$: $f=\{(1,4), (2,5), (3,6)\}$ $g=\{(1,4), (2,5), (3,4)\}$. $h=\{(2,5), (3,6), (1,7)\}$. Which of the following is true? %
step.tex: %text $f$ and $h$ are one-one, $g$ is not one-one. %
%text $f$ and $h$ are not one-one, $g$ is one-one. %
step.reason: %text A function is said to be{\bf one-one} only if for each value in $A$ (in this case), there is a unique corresponding value in $B$. As can be seen, $g(1)=g(3)=4$ which makes $g$ a{\bf many-one} instead of one-one. %
